title: Question Frenzy
description: In this warm-up activity, present a topic, image, or statement and ask students to list as many questions as possible surrounding the stimuli within 2 minutes.

title: I wonder
description: Identify a trend that generates curiosity that also can provide a potential implication related to technology, research, etc. Present 2-3 sentences to accompany the trend. Ask students to list what they wonder within the given timeframe.
example: The confluence of social acceptance and access to technology has created a phenomenon in individual trends. An associated graphic is included in the activity.
tip: The activity can be expanded to introduce a research topic or be used as a class opener.

title: Just google it.
description: Ask students to take 2 minutes to investigate, research a problem, learn how the system works, relevant cases, and prior solutions.

title: Gallery Walk
description: Present a gallery of statements or images by itself or on a large easel post-it pad. Students will be provided 10 minutes to write a question for each “station.” Close the activity by asking the group for takeaways.

title: Google Trends
description: Using Google Trends, students use this data online exploration tool to understand relevant topics that are being searched.

title: On the contrary
description: Present a statement that will spark curiosity. Split groups into teams of 2-3 and ask them to research their stance with facts to support their stance. In a structured manner, students debate the topic.

title: Painstorming
description: Present to students a concept, process, or product that lends itself to many “pains”. Ask students to take 5 minutes to list as many “pains” they have observed in this topic, concept, or product.

title: Bingo!
description: Facilitators will list one big idea related to a larger topic in each box of the grid. Students will list a concept for each. When students identify an entire row horizontally or vertically earns students a Bingo.
